her own load test to figure out if the
promise of running your own production
app on such a low budget is realistic so
she coded up a simple crud app in go
hooked it up to mongod DB because
because relational databases weren't
built for web scale mongodb handles web
scale you turn it on and it scales right
up and deployed it all to a $4 VPS of an
unnamed provider using Docker with
Docker compose she then used k6 an open-
Source load testing Suite that generates
virtual users who continuously run test
scenarios defined in JavaScript to see
what the machine was capable of I feel
the need the need
for
Speed I'll leave out the Gory details

for vs code which Brett helps to
maintain but it might be a good thing to
consider across the broader developer

files they are a very common way of
defining configuration settings outside
of your app code so you can keep them
out of the source control and easily
load them as environment variables at
runtime but but they do have their
problems no wh SS or butts well maybe a

butts big ones the two that Brett lists

Chosen contest count unique visitors to

we declare a
winner use only the dialup access codes
and passwords in your collection can't
ask for any help from us privacy is why
they're doing this and how they're doing
it is the following quote when the
browser pings our server from a website
for the first time we send back a
response with a header set to cach
control no cach telling the browser to
store the request in its cach but
revalidate it with the origin server
before each use but most importantly we
send a header which is a date set to the
beginning of each day from now on every
time this request is made again the
server receives the date and adjusts it
by 1 second and returns it to the
browser this way the server can
calculate the distance in seconds since
B night to give us a visitor count if
that sounds confusing to you check out
